results.title: Olympia: the film of the XI Olympic Games. Part II
results.brief_description: Part two from Leni Riefenstahl’s “Olympia”, a record of the Berlin Games of 1936 and an elegy on the youth of 1936, dedicated to the highest ideals of sportsmanship. In this part, Riefenstahl focusses on the aesthetics of the young virile body of the athletes creating a visual poetry in motion.

results.title: Olympia. [Part I]
results.brief_description: Part one from Leni Riefenstahl’s “Olympia”, a record of the Berlin Games of 1936 and an elegy on the youth of 1936, dedicated to the highest ideals of sportsmanship. Riefenstahl picked a crew of 100 cameramen who shot over a million feet of film which she worked on for 18 months, selecting shots for their beauty rather than for a documentary record. The film focuses essentially on the main stadium track and field events with emphasis on the brute physical competitiveness between the athletes. For Part two of this film see Title Code 507315.

results.title: Playing better tennis
results.creator_credit: Tate Lane and Sports Films and Talents
results.brief_description: America’s top professional tennis players combine playing and coaching skills to show beginners and intermediates the fundamentals of the serve, backhand, forehand, lob, volley and return of serve. Suitable for middle secondary level.

results.title: The Rats of Tobruk
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Charles Chauvel Productions
results.brief_description: Grant Taylor, Peter Finch and Chips Rafferty are cast as three bold Australians in the war-time-morale-boosting feature, recreating war-torn Tobruk in a field near Camden, NSW. Although ostensibly a tribute to the Australian fighting spirits, “The Rats of Tobruk” is dominated less by rhetorical patriotism that by a sense of tragedy and heartbreak of war. George Wallace and Joe Valli appear frequently throughout the film to improvise some comic relief but the mood remains set by the three heroes as they soberly face their responsibilities in the war.

results.title: Heritage
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Australian Expeditionary Films
results.brief_description: Chauvel’s second sound feature was ambitious in scope spanning many decades in Australian history. The films traces the life and loves of James Morrison in colonial times and his descendant Frank Morrison in the 1930s struggling to survive on an outback station with the same determination as his ancestor. Cast, Franklyn Bennett, Norman French, Frank Harvey, Mary Maguire, Harold Meade, Margot Rhys, Joe Valli and Ann Wynn.

results.title: Dad and Dave come to town
results.brief_description: The third film in Cinesound’s ‘Dad and Dave’ series, this film had virtually nothing in common with the Steele Rudd stories and instead was based upon one of Ken Hall’s favourite comic formulae of the ‘fish out of water’. The Rudd family are taken from their usual rural haunts to the city when Dad unexpectedly inherits a women’s fashion emporium. Cast includes Bert Bailey, Shirley Ann Richards, Peter Finch, Fred MacDonald, Billy Rayes, Alec Kellaway, Sidney Wheeler, Connie Martyn, Ossie Wenban, Valerie Scanlan, Muriel Flood, Leila Steppe, Marshall Crosby, Cecil Perry, Billy Stewart, Marie D’Alton and Leslie Victor.

results.title: Tall timbers
results.brief_description: A young forestry graduate, Jim Thornton, is involved in a race between timber companies to fill a major contract. Jim has joined the crew of a genial timber baron, Burbridge, and foils attempts by a rival, Blake, to sabotage their work. J. Alan Kenyon’s special effects are the highlights of the film with comic relief provided by Joe Valli as a Scottish timber-train driver amorously pursued by a shrill-voiced maid of the Burbridge’s country house. Stars Frank Leighton, Shirley Ann Richards and Letty Craydon.

results.title: The Squatter's Daughter
results.brief_description: In his second feature production, Ken Hall retained little but the title of the old play by Bailey and Duggan which had been more faithfully filmed in 1910. Hall’s film focussed on the rivalry between two sheep stations, one managed by a strong willed woman, Joan Enderby and the other by a weak willed enemy, Clive Sherrington. Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur. Cast includes Jocelyn Howarth, Dick Fair, John Warwick, Fred MacDonald.
results.description:
In his second feature production, Ken Hall retained little but the title of the old play by Bailey and Duggan, which had been more faithfully filmed in 1910. Hall’s film focused on the rivalry between two sheep stations; one managed by a strong willed woman, Joan Enderby, and the other by a weak-willed enemy, Clive Sherrington.

Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the Outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur.

Cast includes Jocelyn Howarth, Dick Fair, John Warwick, Fred MacDonald.

Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the Outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur.

results.title: Nonoonse Anishinabe Ishichekewin Ka Kanawentank
results.creator_credit: Elise Swerhone, Sara Berger, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Western pioneers knew that sugar could be made from the sap of the Manitoba maple. But the trees were small, the sap was thin, and the tastier product of Quebec and Ontario was cheap and easy to get. The settler soon turned away from the arduous annual harvest and the Manitoba maple became just another tree. But not for Nonoonse. Forty years ago her grandmother brought her to Sugar Island. Since then she has returned every spring to gather the sweet sap. Filmed on Lake Manitoba, near the Ebb’n’Flow Reserve, Nonoonse is both a clear description of sugar-making and a quiet statement on the importance of the tradition to the Saultaux Indians of the region. (Bilingual: English and Saulteaux.)
